results.name: a(n) = n mod 2 + n mod 4 + ... + n mod 2^k, where 2^k <= n < 2^(k+1).
comment: There is the following connection between this sequence and A080277: A080277(n) = n + n*floor(log_2(n)) - a(n). Since A080277(n) is the solution to a prototypical recurrence in the analysis of the algorithm Merge Sort, that is, T(0) := 0, T(n) := 2*T(floor(n/2)) + n, the sequence a(n) seems to be the major obstacle when trying to find a simple, sum-free solution to this recurrence. It seems hard to get rid of the sum. - Peter C. Heinig (algorithms(AT)gmx.de), Oct 21 2006
When n = 2^k with k > 0 then a(n+1) = k. For this reason, when n-1 is a Mersenne prime then n - 1 = M(p) = 2^p - 1 = 2^a(n+1) - 1 and p = a(n+1) is prime. - _David Morales Marciel_, Oct 23 2015
